repnme.cdata!:
Costa Rica - Global Environmental Facility
            Trust Fund Grant for the Ecomarkets Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Global Environmental
            Facility Trust Fund Grant for the Ecomarkets Project were as
            follows: The Bank's performance was satisfactory and
            the borrower's performance was satisfactory. Lessons
            learned were as follows: 1) Implementing a successful
            environmental services program takes a concerted effort over
            time with political support and an efficient national
            institutional arrangement and equally efficient local
            institutions when the program is decentralized; 2)
            Significant amounts of international donor funding can serve
            as an essential (although not, by itself, sufficient)
            catalyst for inducing important institutional changes
            leading to more effective and efficient biodiversity
            conservation programs; 3) Efforts to induce the private
            sector to enter into voluntary agreements to pay for
            environmental services may be a useful way of strengthening
            the private sector's awareness and understanding of the
            system of payments for ecosystem services, but are unlikely
            to generate significant amounts of funding to support a
            national-level Payment for Environmental Services Program
            (PSA); 4) The Ecomarkets Project's focus on creating
            new markets for ecosystem services, and on the
            Project's substantial budget, appear to have
            facilitated a change in the mindset of key national
            stakeholders, including officials of the Ministry of Finance
            and private sector businesses; 5) Evaluating the
            effectiveness of conservation programs is difficult when
            such programs are not designed to be tested and measured
            against a clear baseline or "control" case; 6)
            While a fixed national price might make political and
            administrative implementation of the program easier, it is
            not necessarily the most efficient; and 7) Identifying
            up-front training needs of the implementing agencies staff
            in order to more effectively implement the project can
            potentially save precious time and avoid unnecessary delays

437703.trustfund: TF023681-GEF2 - COSTA RICA : ECOMARKETS PROJECT,TF022382-GEF2: COSTA RICA ECOMARKETS PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Costa Rica - Ecomarkets Project :
            environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Eco-Markets Project in Costa Rica,
            aims at promoting the development of markets for
            environmental services, from privately-owned forests. These
            services cover carbon sequestration, water resources, and
            bio-diversity protection. The environmental analysis summary
            outlines the eligibility criteria for beneficiaries, and
            describes the environmental service contracts (ESPs),
            establishing the applicable procedures regarding forest, and
            forestry plantations in the country, and promote
            re-forestation, and forest management protection. The
            environmental management plan addresses: 1) forest fire
            prevention, requiring the establishment of fire breaking
            clearances; 2) monitoring activity, to be accomplished by
            forestry inspectors, who should report annually, and
            recommend best practices; 3) reforestation, to be subjected
            to physical, and ecological conditions, i.e., types of soil,
            weather conditions, and, natural drainage. Participants who
            access ESPs, will subject the area under compensation to
            prevention, and control of forest fires, illegal hunting,
            and, extraction of forestry products; will assist the
            State's Forestry Management (SFM) in research, and
            education activities, and, fulfill the commitments
            established in the Forestry Law; will abide by the technical
            recommendations issued by the SFM, and cede - as needed -
            the rights derived from the ESPs to the National Forestry
            Financing Fund.
